**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, any order relative to custody may be modified if there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child, and the modification serves the best interest of the child.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts repeatedly emphasize that custody orders must focus on the **best interest of the child**, considering factors such as parental stability, the child's emotional and developmental needs, and each parent's ability to meet those needs.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames both the physical custody decision and the removal analysis around the children’s best interests and discusses how the judge evaluated the children’s needs, the quality of each parent’s care, and the impact of the mother’s stability and well-being on the children. It explains that “best interests” require attention to the child’s quality of life and the emotional, physical, and developmental needs of the child, and it affirms that these factors are paramount in custody and removal decisions. Thus it squarely supports the proposition about Massachusetts courts’ best-interest focus and the relevant factors considered.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child. There was extensive evidence concerning the children’s relations with their parents. The judge addressed the needs of the children and considered the physical care that each parent gave to each child… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts repeatedly emphasize that custody orders must focus on the **best interest of the child**, considering factors such as parental stability, the child's emotional and developmental needs, and each parent's ability to meet those needs.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the governing standard is the best interests of the child, and then lists concrete factors a judge may weigh, including parental stability, work schedule, keeping siblings together, and whether a parent undermines the child’s relationship with the other parent. The court applies these factors to the facts, focusing on the child’s emotional attachments, developmental needs, each parent’s ability to meet those needs, and the stability of each home. This directly aligns with the claimed proposition.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

**Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1.raw_text: **Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1983) (noting child’s stated preferences may factor into best interest analysis)
**Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1.proposition: Courts also consider the preference of a mature child where appropriate.
**Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the probate judge visited with the almost 10-year-old child, found him to be articulate, and recorded his expressed wishes regarding living arrangements as part of the custody analysis under the best interests standard. The appellate court recounts and relies on these findings in affirming the joint custody order, thereby recognizing that a mature child’s stated preferences may appropriately factor into the best interest determination.
**Doe v. Doe**, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 499 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge visited the parties’ home and spoke with David, almost ten years old at the time of trial. Like the guardian ad litem who had interviewed David, the trial judge found that David is a ‘verbal, intelligent young man who knows what he wants and has the ability to articulate the same. He would prefer to live with both parents under one roof, but if that is not possible, he would like to live with both parents separately.’”

**Pierce v. Pierce**, 455 Mass. 286 (200.proposition: A material change in financial, housing, and personal stability of parents is sufficient to meet the standard for modification.
**Pierce v. Pierce**, 455 Mass. 286 (200.support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony between former spouses, not custody or parenting, and it frames the standard as a “material change of circumstances” evaluated under the G.L. c. 208, § 34 factors (age, health, income, needs, etc.). The court does not articulate or apply a rule that a material change in financial, housing, and personal stability of parents is sufficient for modification; instead, it focuses on retirement, income, need, and ability to pay, and explicitly emphasizes a holistic multi-factor analysis rather than any specific triad of financial, housing, and personal stability factors. Therefore it does not support the proposition as stated.
**Pierce v. Pierce**, 455 Mass. 286 (200.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” … “A court must consider these same factors in determining whether the amount of alimony should be modified based on a change of circumstances following entry of an earlier judgment for alimony. See G. L. c. 208, § 37 (allowing court to modify alimony judgment and ‘make any judgment relative thereto which it might have made in the original action’).”

**Schaffer v. Schaffer**, 43 Mass. App..proposition: In this case, Plaintiff has demonstrated substantial improvement in her stability, living conditions, and availability to care for Sophie, satisfying the requirements set forth in **Schaffer v. Schaffer**, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 746 (1997), and other relevant authorities.
**Schaffer v. Schaffer**, 43 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion in Schaffer v. Schaffer reproduced here is a Massachusetts criminal case about protective custody, medical blood draws, and admissibility of blood-alcohol evidence after an automobile accident. It does not concern child custody, parental fitness, or changes in a parent’s stability, living conditions, or availability to care for a child. Therefore, it cannot provide authority for the proposition that a plaintiff’s improved stability and parenting circumstances satisfy requirements for modifying or deciding custody of a child such as Sophie.
**Schaffer v. Schaffer**, 43 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt:
On these facts, the judge concluded that there was no violation of law in the drawing of the defendant’s blood, and he denied the defendant’s motion to suppress the results of the blood test. The defendant argues that the motion judge was wrong for a number of reasons.

First, the defendant argues that his restraint by the police was unlawful at the outset because he was taken into protective custody in violation of G. L. c. 111B, § 8; he argues that there was no finding, and no evidence to support a finding, that the defendant was “incapacitated” within the meaning of the statute.

**Brooks v. Piela**, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: A parenting plan that denies sufficient time with one parent without justification is contrary to the principle of maximizing a child’s access to both parents.
**Brooks v. Piela**, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support and focuses on how a child’s needs are defined in light of the parents’ respective incomes and standards of living. It does not address parenting time, physical custody schedules, or any principle about maximizing a child’s access to both parents. Because the case is about financial support rather than allocation of parenting time, it does not support the proposition regarding a parenting plan denying sufficient time with one parent.
**Brooks v. Piela**, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Significant to the court’s decision was the fact that ‘[t]he guidelines were promulgated with several fundamental social policies in mind,’ two of which are relevant here: ‘(1) to ‘encourage joint parental responsibility for child support in proportion to, or as a percentage of income’; [and] (2) to ‘meet the child’s survival needs in the first instance, but to the extent either parent enjoys a higher standard of living to entitle the child to enjoy that higher standard’ .... Child Support Guidelines, preamble.’”
